The appropriate control group for a case-control study should ideally have similar characteristics to the case group except for the exposure being studied. In this case, the control group should consist of elderly patients residing in assisted-living facilities, and option D matches this criteria while options A, B, and C do not.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The appropriate control group for a case-control study should be similar to the case group in demographic and clinical factors except for the outcome being studied. Option A is not in an assisted-living facility, and option B is under 65 years old. Option C has a recent hospitalization and stroke, both of which could affect the risk of developing Alzheimer dementia. Option D is the only appropriate control group candidate as the individual is in an assisted-living facility, over 65 years old, and has similar clinical factors to the case group.

Option A is too healthy for the control group, while options B and C have significant health issues that may confound the results.

The control group should be similar to the case group, but without the outcome of interest (Alzheimer dementia) and with similar demographics and risk factors. Among the options, only option D matches the criteria of being over 65 years old, residing in an assisted-living facility, and having mild conditions that are unrelated to the outcome of interest. Option A is inappropriate due to the different living situation and age, option B is inappropriate due to the age, option C is inappropriate due to the recent stroke and coronary artery disease.

Among the options, only an 86-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and mild benign prostate hyperplasia who lives in an assisted-living facility is similar in age, living in an assisted-living facility, and has a similar medical history as the cases. Option A is too young, Option B lives in an independent-living community, Option C has a recent stroke and coronary artery disease, which could affect the outcome of interest.

Option D is the only choice that meets all the criteria and can therefore be appropriate for the study's control group.
